text: A look at how birds live in the city, emphasizing the scavenging nature of their existence. We see birds eating off the ground, out of trash cans, even swooping down to steal a piece of donut out of the hand of a sleepy citize just leaving his house. The last bird we see flies towards the house of the Littl family.
The first hint of morning light enters the Little household. All is quiet and peaceful. MR. AND MRS. LITTLE are asleep in bed. THROUGH the window we see bird eyes spying in on them.
BLASTING a rendition of "STARS AND STRIPES FOREVER" into the Little's bedroom.
The bird flies off the window sill and disappears. Even before they're awake, Mr. and Mrs. Little's feet begin swiveling in time to the music. Then we hear a BABY CRYING.
sitting upright in bed. She turns OFF the ALARM. On her ring finger is a beautiful engagement ring.
Mrs. Little gets out of bed and we FOLLOW her OVER TO a crib wherein sits a beautiful nine-month-old girl, MARTHA LITTLE. Mrs. Little picks her up.
Moomy's here. No more crying. Martha's diaper is askew. (CONTINUED)
Ohh... See this is what happens when Daddy changes you at 4!A.M. (calls out) Boys...
ANOTHER ALARM CLOCK. It GOES OFF and makes a FACTORY WHISTLE NOISE.
in the lower bunk. He grumbles and turns over.

A tiny lump under a blanket as it begins to move. Moments later a tail emerges from underneath the sheet. It moves tentatively, as if checking things out. The tail is followed by a rear-end dressed in bright pajamas with a print pattern featuring pineapples (or something funnier) and then the remainder of a four-inch body. It is STUART. (For those who haven't read the book or seen the movie, Stuart is a mouse.) Stuart is sleepy. He staggers around almost blindly. He almost steps off the edge of his bunk. This wakes him more completely. He rubs his eyes and stretches and smiles. Grabbing hold of a miniature fireman's pole built out of tinker toys, slides down to the lower bunk and crosses over to George's sleeping head.
George, wake up. George is a hard wake-up. Stuart stands on George's chest and jumps up and down.
George.
It's Saturday.
I know. But it's the first day of Pee Wee Soccer. Our first game. (CONTINUED)
George's eyes pop open and he gasps. He's immediately nervous.

Soccer? Uh... No I can't today, I... caught a cold while I was sleeping. He sneezes and blows Stuart halfway across the bed. Stuart scrambles back quickly. He grabs George's glasses from the nightstand and masterfully engineers them onto George's face. He taps on the glasses.
You'll be fine. Come on, we're gonna be great. We're gonna play like Brazilians! Stuart takes off his pajama top and soccer-kicks it acros the room into a hamper.

Mrs. Little is rushing around the kitchen, feeding the baby and making breakfast for everyone at the same time. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her TO the kitchen table as she puts another spoonful of cereal into the baby's mouth. The baby is sitting in her highchair between her brothers who are in their uniforms.
Stuart, don't forget your water bottle. George... Mr. Little enters on the run.
(finishing her sentence) --.- don't forget your cleats. (to Mrs. Little) You look especially beautiful today.
Some people just know how to wear oatmeal. They kiss. MARTHA BABBLES something that is not a word. (CONTINUED)
(excited) Did you hear that? She said ‘bluh-bluh,' her first word. Where's the baby book? I'1l write it down.
I'm... not sure that's actually a word.
Your Uncle Crenshaw said that every Little starts talking by nine months.
Yes and in Uncle Crenshaw's case never stops.
Are you both coming to the game?
Wouldn't miss it.
(sotto) Frederick, this soccer game is making me very...
«+. proud? He starts opening a jar.
(sotto) Anxious. Especially ‘bout... She points at Stuart who is trying to get jelly out of a jar. He almost falls in, but then swings himself out safely onto the table.
I'm fine.
He's fine. (CONTINUED)
(sotto) But all those boys... stomping around with cleats... What if someone...? She pantomimes squishing and recoils.

(sotto) Honey, he's a Little. We're all natural athletes. (handing her the jar) Could you open this? She does. The toast is burning, the TEA is WHISTLING, the BABY is CRYING, and Mrs. Little is clearly overwhelmed. Then the baby pours the remainder of the cereal onto her head and throws the bowl onto the floor. Mrs. Little quickly lifts her from the highchair and rushes her to th sink.
Okay, that's it for you. (calling out) Snowbell. Food.
SNOWBELL perks up.
Food! ! He dashes pell-mell into the kitchen, careening around corners.
Snowbell rushes in.
(excitedly) Tuna? Is it tuna? Or herring. Or -- dare I say it -- is it lox? Oh, please be lox! (CONTINUED)
(points to the glop on the floor) That's for you, Snow.
(disappointed) Oh great. It's glop. (starts eating it) Look what I'm reduced to. I'ma paper towel with hair.
(enthusiastically) How about it, boys? Are we ready to play some soccer?
The game is in progress. George is trying, but some of the kids are bigger, more aggressive and better co- ordinated.
The whole pack blows right by him. Among the parents, Mr. and Mrs. Little watch the game. Mrs. Little holds Martha.
Frederick, why are all the kids running one way while George is going the other way?
Well, he, uh... he's an independent spirit. What bothers me is, every kid has had a chance to play except Stuart.
Well, there's plenty of time.
Plenty of time? There's forty seconds.
He did an excellent job handing out the orange slices. And that's not as easy as it looks. He gives her a look. (CONTINUED)
All right. I admit it. I'm glad he's not in the game. I don't want him to get hurt.
Honey, it's Pee Wee Soccer. Nobody gets hurt.
A KID on George's team gets kicked in the stomach. He howls in pain. A whistle blows, stopping the action. The COACH runs out to help.
Are you all right, Irwin?
(doubled over) Do I look all right?
You'd better substitute.
Only Stuart is available.
(to his assistant) Tie game. We could play with just ten.
(an obnoxious kid) Yeah, but we have George, so it would be like having nine.
Wallace! We'll have none of that.
Why not? That's how you talk to Mom.
Come on, Coach. (CONTINUED)
«+. Stuart. Go in for Irwin.
Yes!! He runs in.
Stuart's teammates look as if this seals their doom.
Yeah, Stuart!
(nervously) Oh my.
(to Stuart) Try to... He gives up. Whistle. Play is back in. The ball is kicked around by a pack of boys. Stuart chases the pack. The pack turns and Stuart is nearly trampled.
(rises) I'm going down there and snatching him off that field. Mr. Little holds her down. (CONTINUED)
The ball comes flying out of the pack towards the goal that George and Stuart's team are attacking. The closest players to the ball are George and Stuart, who were lagging behind the play.
(hysterical) Get it! George! Go after it! George and Stuart from opposite directions run towards th ball. Stuart is closer, but George is faster and is getting to the ball first.
George, shoot! Wallace appears out on the wing.
Pass me the ball, lame-o!

George, shoot! George shuts his eyes and kicks at the exact moment Stuar reaches the ball. The ball flies off the ground with Stuart pasted to it, screaming. The ball hits Wallace -- hard -- in the middle of his face and ricochets off. Wallace, knocked loopy, has the imprint of a mouse on his forehead. The ball -- still flying. Stuart still on it, screaming. It sails into the goal. The GUN GOES OFF. The game is over. George is mobbed by happy teammates. He is literally carried off on their shoulders.
Mr. and Mrs. Little run in to look for Stuart. The ball is on the ground. They pick it up. No Stuart.
I'm all right.
Enmeshed in the goal netting, dangling upside-down by one foot. (CONTINUED)
Do I get an assist? Then he falls several feet into the dust.
They're preparing for bed.
He just looked so small out there. So... lacking in bigness. Does he have to go back next week?
Honey, we have to give him room to grow.
I give him room. I let him drive his car to school. No other mother does that.
Yes, but with George walking right beside him every step.
I let him go out without his galoshes.
When it's not raining.
So? How much more room do I need to give him?
A little more than you're giving him now.
-+. How little?
The boys are in their respective bunks.
I'm worried that Mom's not going to let me play soccer anymore. (CONTINUED)
She wouldn't do that.
Well, she already didn't let me go out for fencing or wrestling or roller hockey.
Well, what does she want you to go out for?
Painting or dancing.
It's hard to get hurt doing those.
(glumly ) Yeah...
I guess it's my fault. I'm sorry I kicked you into the goal.
That's okay. Hey, you won the game. That's the main thing.
No... the main thing was I hit Wallace in the face. They both laugh.
Mrs. Little is pruning roses in a tiny planter in front o the house. She hears:
Hello, Mrs. Little. She looks up and sees WILL WILSON. He's George's age, African-American.
Oh hi, Will.
Is George home? (CONTINUED)
Yes. He's playing with Stuart. Go on in.

George and Stuart are working on a model airplane that ha taken over the dining table. It is a bright-red replica of a WWII Grumman F4F-3 Wildcat fighter plane with a deca of an American flag and Betty Grable on the side. George is putting the propeller on. Stuart is vocally making engine noises.
Stuart, hand me the pliers... Stuart? Stuart is sitting in the plane, a scarf around his neck, fantasizing.
Bogie's, twelve o'clock! I got him, Brooklyn!
Stuart!
(brought back to reality) Huh?
What are you doing?
Oh -- I... Wouldn't it be cool if I actually flew this thing?
Yeah. Mom's gonna let you fly a plane. Check the wires in there. Will enters.
Hi, George. Hi, Stuart. (CONTINUED)
(delighted) Hi.
Hi, Will.
Hey, neat plane.
Thanks.
Hey, George, you want to take a break for awhile? I brought my chess set.
Yeah, okay.
But what about the plane?
I want to play with Will for awhile. We can tell Stuart is dejected and that this is for him. The older boys exit. Stuart turns to sleeping on the work table.
Hey, Snowbell? (louder) Snowbell1! 13. 12 painful Snowbell Snowbell, wakes up, noisily -- snorting and clearing his throat.
Whu?
Want to help me fix the plane?
Let me explain something to you. I am trying -- desperately -- to cling to the last shreds of dignity I possess. I'm licking up after that little monster... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

«+. I've had my claws trimmed so I won't scratch 'Mommy's Little Precious'... and now a mouse -- because he's lonely and desperate for companionship asks -- as a last resort -- to become his ‘playmate.’ The gall. The temerity... Yeah, okay.

Stuart climbs back into the cockpit of the PLANE. He opens up the instruction book. He reaches under the dashboard. His sweater catches on the on/off switch and clicks it ON by accident. Suddenly the MOTOR WHIRS into action. Snowbell, hearing the noise, screams, jumps up and dashes out. Before Stuart realizes what is happening, the airplane is taxiing down the table. George and Will run in and yell over the NOISE of the ENGINE.
Stuart, what are you doing?

(panicked, yelling back) I'm not doing it. It won't turn off. The plane hits the remote, knocking it off the table. It breaks. The plane flies off the table and into the next room. George and Will run after it. As they enter the dining room, the PLANE BUZZES their heads.
Stuart!
This is cool! All my brother does is jam crayons up his nose. (CONTINUED)
Snowbell runs in. The PLANE BUZZES him and he dashes into the kitchen.
Mr. Little is coming downstairs with a paper kite.
Who wants to help me fly the kite? The PLANE RIPS through the kite.
Sorry, Dad.
Stuart. Stop that this minute. George and Will run in.
He can't. Stuart yells, frightened.
At least he's indoors, nothing bad can happen. At that exact moment, Mrs. Little opens the front door, carrying a freshly-cut bouquet.
Have you ever seen prettier roses? The PLANE RIPS through the bouquet and flies outside.
Stuart! All the Littles run outside.

They chase Stuart across Fifth Avenue into the park. Stuart has rose petals stuck to his face, blinding him. Screaming, he frantically brushes them off -- just in tim to see a group of nuns. He barely avoids hitting them. (CONTINUED)

Stuart covers his eyes and screams as the plane disappear behind some bushes. We hear STUART SCREAM, then we hear the sound of a CRASH. When Stuart opens his eyes, he discovers that both he and the plane have collided with a thick bush and both wings are dangling precariously at the side. Stuart crawls out of the wreckage and scampers down to th ground. We hear the anxious voices of the entire Little family as they race toward him.
Stuart! Stuart! Are you all right?
I'm okay. Everything's fine.
Fine?! It's ruined! Stuart, you destroyed it!
(feeling like a failure) I didn't mean to, George. I'm sorry. I'm really sorry. We'll fix it.
No, you won't! That is going in the trash. It's much too dangerous.
(sarcastic) Thanks, Stuart. George picks up the wreckage, throws it in the trash, and leaves.
(to Mrs. Little) Now, honey --
He could easily have been killed. Painting or dancing. Those are his choices. And I'm no longer too sure about dancing -- you don't know what can happen. I'll make lunch. (CONTINUED)
She leaves. Stuart and Mr. Little are alone.
Since she has Little Martha her protective, maternal instincts are running somewhat amok.
I'll say.
Also she just loves you so much, Stuart... it's hard for her to think of you in danger.
This has been a bad day. Mom wants me to paint, George is mad at me and you and Mom are fighting.
Well... it's not one of our best days, but it's not that bad. The thing about being a Little is you always see the bright side. Every cloud has a silver lining.
Every cloud?

Stuart is sitting at a miniature school desk on the top o a regular school desk. He is dwarfed by a huge book propped open on a stand before him. We hear everyone in the class turning the page. Stuart crosses over to his book, grabs hold of the bottom of the mammoth page, and walks it from one side of the book to the other.
Okay, does anyone know the difference between longitude and latitude?
We scan the class. Nobody moves. A BOY in the rear cautiously volunteers. (CONTINUED)
Is that like when somebody has a bad latitude?
No. Interesting try, though. Anybody else? Stuart peers out from behind his book and raises his tiny hand.
Stuart.
Longitude and latitude refer to the imaginary lines that go around the Earth, that help us measure where we are. Longitude measures east and west, latitude measures north and south.
(pleased) Now there's a boy who's done his homework. Very good, Stuart. Very good. A few KIDS look at him and roll their eyes. Someone whispers.
Teacher's pet.
Yeah? What about the hamster? A few kids giggle. A SCHOOL BELL RINGS signalling the end of the school day. Kids jump out of their seats and hurry for the door.
The hallway is lined with lockers. Stuart's locker is smaller than the others. As Stuart tosses things into his locker, kids prepare to go home. Stuart calls to a BOY at a nearby locker. (CONTINUED)
Hey, Tony, I was wondering if you'd like to come over to my house this afternoon?
Hey, sorry, pal, I can't. Soccer practice.
(nods understandingly and turns to another boy) Hey, Mark...?
Piano lessons.
Hey, Irwin?
A creepy-looking kid with his shirt mis-buttoned and sticking through his fly. Irwin is aggressively picking his nose.
Yeah?

Uh... Nothing. Stuart slides down his desk and gets into a tiny red car parked alongside it. He puts his knapsack in the back seat and takes off following a red line painted alongside the lockers just for him. He HONKS whenever someone gets in his way. Suddenly George runs over to him.
Hey, Stu, some of the guys are going over to Will's to play basketball for a while.
Can I come?
(uncomfortably) Well, they... didn't exactly mention that you were invited. (CONTINUED)
Oh... that's okay. I'm busy anyway.
Just tell Mom I walked you home, okay? George runs off. Stuart, nodding sadly, drives off alone.

Stuart is driving quietly down the sidewalk. He's gone abaut a block when suddenly he hears a loud SQUAWK and then sees what appears to be a wounded BIRD fall out of the sky and land in the passenger seat of his car.

Oh, my -- ! Startled, her swerves the CAR all over the sidewalk until SCREECHING to a stop. He stares at the bird, lying in his car. Although, we don't know it yet, her name is MARGALO. Stuart stares at her with a mixture of concern and fascination. She is definitely a unique creature, not much bigger than Stuart. She is wearing a pilot's leather helmet, and goggles and looks like what Amelia Earhart might have looked like if she was a bird. Cautiously he reaches out to touch her.
Miss?... Miss?... Are you alive? She doesn't answer. Stuart listens for her heartbeat.
She's alive! Slamming on the gas pedal, Stuart RACES quickly down the sidewalk.
Out of the way, please. Injured bird, coming through.
(CONTINUED)
The shadow of a huge bird crosses over it. We hear Jaws- like theme MUSIC.
Stuart and Margalo are zipping through pedestrian traffic when she opens her eyes and looks groggily at Stuart.
What's going on? Where am I?
It's all right. You're going to be okay.
(looks around) But where's Falcon?
Falcon? What Falcon? At that instant, a huge terrifying BIRD swoops down from the sky. All Stuart can make out is a sharp beak and terrifying pointed talons rushing at him. Margalo yells to Stuart.
That Falcon!! Drive! Get out of here!
Oh, my!!! Stuart GUNS the CAR and goes shooting down the sidewalk. Margalo turns defiantly in the back seat and waves her fist at the bird.
Get lost, you disgusting vulture!
(nervously) Do we really want to antagonize him? (CONTINUED)
Just drive! (cursing again at the hawk) Eat_my feathers, you vile buzzard!

See, you're just reducing yourself to his level. Stuart drives faster. People scatter in all directions. A metal grate begins to open like a drawbridge on the sidewalk in front of him. Stuart can't get around it.
Uh-oh, we've got a problem.
You can make it! Don't slow down. Like Smokey and the Bandit, he takes a deep breath, aims full-speed at the grate, and goes sailing over the top.
as they are careening through the air.
See! What'd I tell ya? Stuart's eyes are lit up with excitement. He is thrilled.
Yeah!!!!

lands safely on the down-sloping grate and continues alon the sidewalk, but the massive bird is still in full pursuit. Stuart SCREECHES around a corner and spots a stack of plumbing supplies piled in front of a building. He zooms into an eight-foot long plastic pipe, about six inches in diameter. Peering out the far end he can see Falcon landing on the ground and looking around in total confusion. He has lost them. The Falcon flies away. Stuart lets out a deep sigh. Margalo looks up at Stuart and whispers. (CONTINUED)
Nice going, friend.
Friend? He smiles.
Stuart is wrapping her wing with gauze. A doll's medical kit is open beside him.
I wish my mom were here. She'd do a much better job. Why don't we take off your scarf.
Good idea. I -- She gasps.
What happened?
My pin. It's...
With a pearl on the head of it. However, part of the pearl is gone, leaving a jagged crater.
It must have happened when Falcon smashed into me.
(sympathetically) Oh, gee, that's too bad.
Yeah... (CONTINUED)
Hey, who was that big bird? And why was he after you?
Falcon? Oh, I accidentally flew into his territory.
His territory?
Yeah. He thinks he owns the sky. Well, he can't tell me where to fly!... Although if you hadn't shown up... Hey, who are you anyway?
Oh. (bows ) Forgive me. My name is Stuart. Stuart Little.
I'm Margalo. She curtseys.
(loves her name) Margalo...
So tell me, Stuart Little, do you actually live here?
Oh yeah. I'ma real Little. I'm the middle child. The middle Little.
Cute. You got some nice digs here. Very plush.
Where do you live?
Well, I'm kind of, uh... I don't exactly... (CONTINUED)
(gently) Are you... homeless?
Well... yeah. Now I don't mind, 's you understand. I like it. It 25. 19 just now with my injured wing, if I have to go back out on the street, well... Hey, I'll survive.
Oh no, you can't go back out on
the street, not while you're hurt.
Well um... is there anyplace around here I can crash?
Crash? You already crashed.
No. I mean is there anyplace around here I can lie down for a while? Maybe just a little box? You know like one of those jewelry boxes with those soft linings? like those.
I know just the thing. I'1l be right back. Meanwhile, you can use my cat's bed. Margalo recoils.
You have a cat?!
Oh, don't worry about Snowbell. He wouldn't hurt a fly.
Snowbell sees a fly. Quick as a wink, he air and swallows it.
I've had better, I've had worse. He heads for the house.
20 jumps into the  21 26.
Snowbell enters the kitchen through the "doggy" door and saunters over to his water bowl. Suddenly he sees Margalo in his bed and nearly jumps out of his skin.
Aaaa!!
Sorry. I didn't mean to scare you.
Scare me! That's a laugh. (laughs) Hear that? That was a laugh. Snowbell now goes through a series of threatening poses and hissing sounds, then starts choking.
Hairball. Major hairball. He clears his throat.
And yet we continue to lick ourselves. Unbelievable. Stuart returns.
Hey, Snowbell, meet Margalo. She's going to be staying with us for a while.

Staying?! Are you out of your mind? Stuart, you can't just drag stray birds in here. What do you think this is, a halfway house? It's not sanitary. I mean, look at her, she's filthy -- no offense. She could have germs. And how do you know she's not a vagrant or a thief? Am I being too vague? Get rid of her! Mrs. Little's voice can be heard coming from the doorway.
Hi, we're home. Sorry we're late. (CONTINUED)
(yells) Little hi, Little low.
Little hey, Little ho.
What the heck was that?
(a little embarrassed) Oh, that's... how we greet each other.
Interesting.
(pleased) Never mind. You're in for it now. Mrs. Little hates when animals walk in here off the street. She chases my friends out with a broom. When she sees this, she's going to throw a fit.
Mrs. Little standing over Margalo, cooing.
Ooohhh... such a pretty little birdie. She cups Margalo in her hands and lifts her up, making kissing noises. Snowbell shakes his head.
I don't understand. If I live to be eight, I will never understand.
I found her.
Found me? He did more than that. He saved my life.
He did? (CONTINUED)
Mom, can she crash here?

OPEN ON a jewelry box that has been converted into an ornate bedroom suite. A tiny ballerina swirls on the uppermost level of the box and below it there is a holder for a tiny toothbrush and a bar of soap. The bottom drawer has been pulled out and turned into a bed, complet with a lace doily for a bedspread. It is a surprisingly opulent setting.
What do you think? REVEAL Margalo gazing at her new "home" as Stuart waits expectantly for her reaction. Mr. and Mrs. Little watch from a discreet distance. Margalo turns away.
What? What don't you like? Margalo sniffles and wipes her eyes with her good wing.
I never... I mean nobody ever... it's so beautiful. Stuart is very happy.
But where will your mother keep her jewelry? Mrs. Little steps forward.
Oh, don't worry about that. The only thing I really value is my engagement ring. She shows it. Sunlight coming through the window, catches the ring and it shines very brightly.
Wow, that's beautiful. (CONTINUED)
It's been worn for five generations of Little women, I don't mean little women, I -- well, let's just say it's very, very special to me.
But now where will you keep it?
Oh, I never take it off. Except to do the dishes.
Ah...
And half the time I do ‘em.
Well, I'll just stay ‘til my wing heals.
Stay as long as you like. Mr. and Mrs. Little exit.
Just remember. Guests are like fish. After two days they start to stink.
We hear MARTHA WAILING away. CLOSEUP of a dish of glop hitting the floor.
Snowbell... Snowbell reluctantly starts licking up the glop.
How about I spill something and we get the kid to lick it up?
feeding Margalo with a little spoon. (CONTINUED)
He laughs. She exits. 30. 24
Stuart, I'm full.
Full? You eat like a bird.
Come on, Stuart, time for school.
Oh, I'm not going to school today.
Oh, you're not?
No. I'm staying home to take care of Margalo...
(sweetly) Well, guess again. You are going to school and I'll take care of Margalo. And wear your rubbers and in art class don't run with scissors. I'1l get your backpack.
Stuart's a little embarrassed.
(to Margalo) She's a little over-protective. You know... mothers.
Well, I don't really know.
No?
See, my mom just kinda one day... wasn't there anymore.
Oh. (CONTINUED)
It's kind of hard even to remember her now... I only remember two things. She used to sing to me and she... gave me that pearl pin...
Oh... the one that broke?
Yeah. It was part of our nest when I was a baby. I've had it ever since.
Gee, I'm sorry. (impressed) So you've been completely on your own all your life.
You bet.
I'll bet it's been scary.
Hey... it's been an adventure.
I wish I had some adventures. I'm only allowed to paint.
Hey, life is an adventure. Just walking out that door is an adventure.
Snowbell enters.
Has anyone seen my tinkle ball? George appears with his schoolbooks in tow.
Come on, Stu. We're late.
(to Stuart) Go for it, kid. The adventure begins.  25 26 27 32.
Stuart steps outside the front door and immediately trips over Snowbell's tinkle ball and rolls down the front steps. He stands up, shakes his head to clear it.
Well, that feels like enough adventure for one day. He turns and is immediately whacked by a thrown rolled-up newspaper. Again, he clears his head.
Martha in a stroller. Mrs. Little is taking her out for a walk.
Margalo, Martha and I are going out for awhile.
Okay.

(to Martha) Say, bye, birdie. Bye... (discouraged) Nothing. They exit. Margalo is alone. She flaps her wings a little, but the bandage is restricting her. Looking around to make doubly certain that she's alone, she removes the bandage.
(pleased) Ahhh... She takes off and flies. She goes out the window and on to the roof.
She lands and breathes in the fresh air.

Fresh air... From behind her we see the falcon soaring above. Margalo doesn't know he's there. The falcon draws a bead on her and swoops down straight at her -- closer and closer, until... he lands right behind her. Margalo turns, startled. (CONTINUED)
He laughs. 33. 27
Falcon! (whispers) ... You scared me.
(slightly sarcastic) Aw, I'm sorry. How's it going, babe!
(nervously) Fine...
Yeah? Well, then what's holding things up?
Well, I --
You've been here two days. How long does it take to steal one little ring? Usually, you're in and out the same day.
She only takes the ring off to do the dishes and the last two nights her husband did them.
Aw, that's sweet. Does he wear a little apron?
Hey, don't pressure me, okay? Have I ever let you down?
(with real admiration) Never. You're the best. The best girl I ever had working for me. I never saw anybody do the injured wing scam like you do it. ‘Help me, save me, the big falcon is after me.'
Speaking of which you hit me kind of hard. You broke my pin. (CONTINUED)
What? That stupid thing your mother gave you? Trash. I wouldn't pick my nose with it. Look, take all the time you need. Just get me that ring. He flies off.

Mr. and Mrs. Little and George are at the table. Mr. Little nudges Mrs. Little and they glance down. On the floor, near the big table is a little table set fo two. Stuart gallantly holds out a chair for Margalo who sits down. Stuart serves her a tiny hamburger on a bun, then picks up a handful of peas from a small serving bowl He juggles the peas. He then gets them to roll down his arm into her plate. He smiles proudly. Just then, a pea lands on his head, squishing. He winces. Margalo bursts out laughing. Stuart wipes the pea off his head and smiles.
Mrs. Little prepares to do the dishes. She takes off her ring. Margalo notices. O.S. MARTHA CRIES.
Oh... Mr. Little enters.
You go ahead, I'1l do the dishes.
Oh, but you did them last night.
For you I would do dishes every night.
Aww... She kisses him and exits. (CONTINUED)
(sotto, to Margalo) I just didn't want to change the baby. (with distaste) Phui. He laughs. Margalo forces a laugh.
Stuart and Margalo are in the front seat of Stuart's car. They're sharing popcorn and are apparently at a drive-in movie, because we can hear DIALOGUE from an old romantic MOVIE.
Are you cold?
Uh-uh. REVEAL that they are watching an old movie on a portable television.
I guess when the weather gets too cold you'll just... fly south?

Wet. Looking up from STUART'S POV, we can see glimpses of his father's eyes looking down at him and occasional views of the kitchen ceiling growing further and further away. It is like he is viewing the world from the wrong end of a telescope.
